title: Nastaliq
content:
**[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20120424141143/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices) : [Writing Systems](http://web.archive.org/web/20120424141143/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Writing%20Systems) : [Arabic](http://web.archive.org/web/20120424141143/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Arabic) : Nastaliq, scholarly transcribed as <cite>nastaʿlîq</cite>**

The name is a contraction of the Persian <cite>naskh-i taʿlîq</cite> which contains the element <cite>naskh</cite> "to copy a manuscript" and <cite>taʿlîq</cite> "to slant", connected by the conjunction <cite>-i</cite>. The name could be paraphrased as "cursive for manuscripts".

Nastaliq is a simplified derivative of historical, pre-typographic naskh. It retains all the connection rules characteristic of pre-typographic Arabic, be it that they are considerably less complex than those of pre-typographic naskh.

From a purely Western typographical perspective, nastaliq is considered to be "very complex". Ironically and apparently paradoxically, the first accurate metal typeface produced in the Arabic-scripted world - using Western typographic technology - was based on nastaliq.
